conduct.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to carry out a particular activity or process, especially in order to get information or prove facts
conduct.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: The memorial service was conducted by the Rev. David Prior.
It was the first time that I had conducted business in Brazil.
We are conducting a survey of consumer attitudes towards organic food.
Is it really necessary to conduct experiments on animals?
They conducted a campaign of bombings and assassinations.
The interview was conducted in English.
conduct.translation[0].definitions[0].no: In everyday English, people usually say do or carry out rather than conduct:
They’re doing a survey of opinions about organic food.
conduct.translation[0].definitions[1].de: to stand in front of a group of musicians or singers and direct their playing or singing
conduct.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: The orchestra is conducted by John Williams.
conduct.translation[0].definitions[2].de: if something conducts electricity or heat, it allows electricity or heat to travel along or through it
conduct.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: Aluminium, being a metal, readily conducts heat.
conduct.translation[0].definitions[3].de: to take or lead someone somewhere
conduct.translation[0].definitions[3].ex: On arrival, I was conducted to the commandant’s office.
conduct.translation[0].note_box[0].secti: He’s conducting educational research at the University of Washington.
They conducted a survey of students’ careers one year after graduation.
Scientists conducted a study of the area affected by the nuclear disaster.
Experts conducted an investigation into the causes of the crash.
Here are a few guidelines on how to conduct an interview.
The party was criticized for the way it had conducted its election campaign.
Investigators will be conducting tests to determine how the man died.
The Spanish authorities conducted a nationwide search for the girl.
The company had been conducting a lot of business in Latin America.
conduct.translation[1].definitions[0].de: the way someone behaves, especially in public, in their job etc
conduct.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: The Senator’s conduct is being investigated by the Ethics Committee.
an inquiry into the conduct of the police
his arrest for disorderly conduct (=noisy violent behaviour)
the Law Society’s Code of Professional Conduct
conduct.translation[1].note_box[0].secti: professional conduct
There are strict rules that regulate lawyers’ professional conduct.
sexual conduct
The politician’s sexual conduct had caused scandal.
violent conduct
Their goalkeeper was sent off the field for violent conduct.
disorderly conduct
Her husband was arrested for drunkenness and disorderly conduct.
criminal conduct
In some cases of bullying, pupils may be guilty of criminal conduct.
proper/improper conduct
There was no evidence of improper conduct on the part of the police.
personal conduct
You are expected to maintain a high standard of personal conduct at work.
unsportsmanlike conduct
He swore at the referee, and was penalized for unsportsmanlike conduct.
human conduct
Societies have certain rules for normal human conduct.
a code of conduct
All professions have a code of conduct.
rules/standards of conduct
In war, there are established rules of conduct.
a course of conduct
The court said that when Harris had embarked on this course of conduct, he knew that it would put lives at risk.
conduct.translation[2].definitions[0].ex: In future, Mr O'Reilly will conduct his business within the rules and regulations.
The Special Fund may, in his name, finalise contractual issues.
conduct.translation[2].definitions[1].de: to carry out an activity or process in order to obtain information or prove facts
conduct.translation[2].definitions[1].ex: The European Parliament had asked its legal affairs committee to conduct an investigation into the case.
conduct.translation[2].definitions[2].de: to behave in a particular way, especially in a situation where other people judge your behaviour
conduct.translation[2].definitions[2].ex: Members of staff should conduct themselves in an appropriate manner when dealing with customers.
conduct.translation[3].definitions[0].de: the way in which a person behaves
conduct.translation[3].definitions[0].ex: It was claimed that the company had engaged in anti-competitive conduct.
conduct.translation[3].definitions[1].de: the way in which something is managed or organized
conduct.translation[3].definitions[1].ex: There has been a huge change in the conduct of monetary policy.
rules governing the conduct of shareholder meetings
